Xiping Road No. 5340, Beichen District Tianjin 300401 PR China Lipids represent a crucial and promising source of alternative liquid hydrocarbons through catalytic pathways. However, catalytic performance of catalysts has been hindered by issues such as coking and low selectivity towards hydrocarbons with desirable carbon distribution. This review critically examines the establishment and application of hierarchically porous structures in catalytic pyrolysis of lipids, exploring their potential as an innovative approach in renewable energy production and resource utilization. The study further investigates the synthesis methods and catalytic performance of hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts, encompassing various techniques such as hard-templating, soft-templating, and non-templating approaches. Various materials, such as carbonaceous substances, polymers, and inorganics, are utilized as sacrificial templates for the hard-templating method. The soft-template methods have the advantages of tunable size, adjustable functionality, and more versatility. Furthermore, the article discusses post-synthesis treatments involving demetalation and chemical leaching. It is noted that hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts demonstrate enhanced catalytic performance due to improved diffusion properties. Future research can emphasize the understanding of synergistic effects between micropores and mesopores and operation cost reduction of catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Microalgae Lipids Catalytic pyrolysis Liquid hydrocarbon Hierarchically porous structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the development of economy and society worldwide, fossil fuel-based hydrocarbon fuels have been depleted with unavoidable environmental pollution and CO2 emission. To address the issues associated with fossil fuel utilization, a considerable number of alternative and clean biomass resources have been developed. Various conversion pathways have been employed for biomass resources, including fermentation, gasification and Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, combustion, hydrothermal liquefaction, hydrotreatment, and catalytic pyrolysis [1]. Among the range of conversion pathways explored, catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids emerges as an alternative for producing liquid hydrocarbon fuels. This approach offers several advantages, including the absence of hydrogen consumption and operation under mild reaction conditions, typically conducted at atmospheric pressure and within the temperature range of 300–500℃ [2]. Catalytic pyrolysis converts non-edible lipids into hydrocarbons via decarboxylation and decarbonylation reactions [3,4], and the element of oxygen in lipid molecular is mainly eliminated as CO and CO2. However, the yield and selectivity of liquid hydrocarbon fuel production in catalytic pyrolysis heavily rely on catalysts employed. Catalysts play a pivotal role in catalytic pyrolysis processes for converting non-edible lipids into alternative hydrocarbon biofuels. They serve multiple functions, including deoxygenation, aromatization, carbon chain cracking, and isomerization [3,5]. The main types of catalysts include aluminosilicate, bulk metal oxides, zeolites, carbon materials, and their combination (composite catalysts) [6]. Deoxygenation is mainly realized via active metals or their oxides, while zeolites as support can realize the functions of carbon chain cracking and aromatization. Meanwhile, the degree of carbon chain cracking depends on porous structure of catalysts, i.e., the ratio of micropores, mesopores and macropores. It is because that these different pores presents a role of molecular sieve for pyrolysis reactants and products. Among the catalysts mentioned, zeolites and their modifications have gained significant popularity in the field of catalytic cracking, particularly for heavy oil and bulky molecules [7,8]. Table 1 The main problems for zeolite catalysts are fast coking and low selectivity on desired products during catalytic pyrolysis [9]. Coking is a severe problem affecting the activity and lifetime of these catalysts, which should be improved efficiently. The main reason for coking in zeolites is their limited mass transfer of micropores. It is important to consider the limitation imposed by the micropores of catalysts. Due to their small size, large reaction molecules are incapable of entering the micropores and reacting with the active sites. Similarly, once the catalytic pyrolysis reactions occur, the resulting products face difficulties in escaping from the confines of the active sites situated within the micropores, which both result in coking in external and internal surface of catalysts at the high reaction temperature. Besides, the selectivity of catalysts is also needed to improve because that more electric automobiles will be applied and gasoline consumption will be restrained in the future. On the contrary, the consumption of alternative aviation fuels is increasing quickly due to increasingly stricter regular/laws of air environmental protection and heavy air traffic worldwide [10], which require the increased selectivity on kerosene in catalytic pyrolysis products. Table 2 Hierarchically porous structures, especially catalysts with micropores and mesopores, are often used to enhance the anti-coking ability of catalysts and also modify the selectivity on hydrocarbon products including gasoline, kerosene, and diesel [11,12]. Considering the background of hierarchically porous zeolites, incorporating secondary mesopores or macropores is an effective approach to enhance the diffusion ability and performance of catalysts. These larger pores contribute to increased surface area and enhanced accessibility of catalytic sites, causing enhanced catalytic activity and selectivity. The large-sized lipid molecule exhibits facile diffusion ingress and egress of catalytic sites, thereby suppressing coke formation. The selectivity of gasoline, kerosene, and diesel in catalytic pyrolysis can be influenced by the ratio of micropores and mesopores within the catalysts. This hierarchically pore structure serves as a fundamental factor in establishing the cracking strength and final length of carbon chains produced during catalytic process. The main synthesis methods for hierarchically porous structures in catalysts include hard templates, soft templates, non-templates, and post-synthesis methods, which have more detailed subclasses or categories [13,14]. More detailed categories can be confirmed further based on the different organic or inorganic templates, monovalent or multivalent surfactants with various functional groups and delicate synthesis strategies, which will be detailedly reviewed in Sections 2 and 3 with the focus on their synthesis methods and catalytic performance (activity and selectivity). Nowadays, the feedstock of catalytic pyrolysis is shifting to alternative biomass to realize near zero CO2 emission, especially non-edible lipids. Microalgal lipids are an potential source of non-edible lipids because of the obvious advantage of fast growth, high photosynthetic efficiency, and no competition with conventional agricultural lands for microalgae feedstock [15,16]. Microalgae can also be cultivated in various water environments such as waste water and sea water. There are many related reviews focusing on specific synthesis strategies for hierarchically porous catalysts. However, the application of hierarchically porous catalysts in non-edible lipids, especially microalgal lipids, is less informative to guide the further utilization of lipids. Within the scope of this review, we concisely summarized the synthetic approaches employed for the preparation of hierarchically porous structures in zeolite catalysts. The effect of these structures (microporous, mesoporous, and hierarchical catalysts) on catalytic activity and selectivity on catalytic pyrolysis products during pyrolysis of lipids was summarized. Special focus is also paid on catalytic pyrolysis of microalgal lipids with hierarchically porous zeolites. In this review, we firstly introduce the in-situ synthesis of hierarchically porous catalysts and their catalytic performance (Section 2). Then, the post-synthesis pathways for hierarchically porous catalysts and their catalytic performance are detailed summarized (Section 3). Finally, the application potential of these different synthesis methods in catalytic cracking processes are summarized and compared for their advantages and disadvantages (Section 4). The future suggestion of research activities is also suggested and presented in Section 4. However, most of description about these synthesis pathways are focused on the characteristics of prepared hierarchically porous catalysts and their catalytic performance during catalytic pyrolysis of lipids, rather than the detailed steps during the synthesis of these catalysts. 2 In-situ synthesis and catalytic performance of hierarchically porous catalysts Diffusion plays a crucial role in zeolite-based catalysis reactions, especially when it comes to the conversion of bulky molecules [11,17]. Numerous synthesis pathways have been developed for the formation of zeolites exhibiting hierarchical porosity. The main synthesis methods of hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts are shown in Fig. 1, mainly including templating methods (hard-templating and soft-templating ones), non-templating methods, and post-synthesis methods (demetallation, delamination, and recrystallization) [13]. These methods are firstly introduced briefly as follows to provide necessary background information for further review about their catalytic performance and reaction mechanism. 2.1 Hard-templating method The hard-templating methods find broad application in the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites, wherein solid materials displaying a stiff structure are often employed as sacrificial frameworks. These templates boost porosity throughout the zeolite crystal growth process. Hard-templating reagents used in the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites encompass a diverse array of materials, including carbonaceous materials, polymers, aerogels, resins, inorganic solids, and even biological materials [18,19]. Most of them are removed from the prepared hierarchically porous zeolites by treatment of high-temperature combustion or etching of acidic/alkaline chemical reagents. This section reviews the related research about the application of these hierarchically porous zeolites synthesized via hard-templating methods during catalytic pyrolysis of lipids to liquid biofuels. Carbonaceous materials, such as active carbon, charcoal, graphite and multi-wall carbon nanotube, are frequently utilized as hard templates for the synthesis of hierarchically porous materials [20,21]. For example, hierarchically porous ZSM-5 zeolite with crystal lattice structure was synthesized by utilizing hydroxylated carbon nanotubes as templates, which reinforced the compatibility with zeolite crystal precursors. The prepared zeolite material exhibited mesopores, particle dimensions ranging from 10 to 35 nm, which closely matched the diameters of the carbon nanotube templates. It also presented clear wall-crystallized mesopores in the zeolite crystals. The results confirmed that constructed layered pore network in the ZSM-5 zeolite served two important functions of enabling the cracking process of bulky molecules and suppressing excessive cracking of small guest molecules with the assistance of hierarchical structure [22]. A carbon template over nickel nanoparticles on silica gel was in situ synthesized, which was further used for synthesis of hierarchically zeolite catalysts. The carbon template was in situ formed via carbon deposition in a CH4 flow, which was followed by crystallization of ZSM-5 and calcination at 550 ℃. The hierarchically porous zeolite obtained in this study exhibited an intracrystalline mesoporous architecture of about 17 nm in diameter and a significant pore volumetric capacity of 0.4 cm3/g. Importantly, this hierarchically porous zeolite demonstrated higher catalytic activity compared to its parent zeolite [23]. Moreover, in the production of bio-based aromatic hydrocarbons via crude glycerol the hydroxylated carbon nanotubes were also used as a hard template for synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites with the crystallinity of 94.9%, Si/Al ratio of 26.6 and mesopore volume of 0.18 cm3/g, which could deal with the issues of separation of carbon template and zeolitic precursors. The prepared hierarchically porous catalyst (HZSM-5/CNT-OH) realized higher yields of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and coke during the aromatization process of crude glycerol, which was due to the smaller crystal sizes, abundant amount of Brønsted acid, uniform and large mesopore diameters [24]. In summary, the size and distribution of mesopores in hierarchically porous zeolites prepared via carbon materials as template can be controlled by flexible selection of carbon materials with different dimension. Polymers, such as P123 (a polyethylene oxide-polypropylene oxide-polyethylene oxide triblock copolymer), PK3 (OH-[CH2-C6H10-CH2-O-C(CH3)2-O]78%-[C5H10-O-C(CH3)2-O]22%-*) and polystyrene spheres, are commonly applied as a hard template for the fabrication of layered porous materials [25,26]. In a specific example, the polymer PK3 with molecular weight of 3.9 kDa was employed as a framework for synthesizing an aluminum-rich hierarchically porous ZSM-5 zeolite. Notably, PK3 is a polymer devoid of nitrogen and halogen constituents. The obtained zeolite possessed a Si/Al ratio of 8 and featured several mesopores comprising oriented-assembled nanocrystals. The polymer PK3 was utilized as a hard template to construct this hierarchically micro/mesoporous structure instead of environment-unfriendly quaternary ammonium templates. The prepared hierarchically porous structure exhibited improved catalytic efficiency in the transformation of plastic waste into useful hydrocarbons in comparison with a commercially available alternative [25]. Besides, a triblock copolymer pluronic P123 (EO20PO70Eo20, MW = 5800, Aldrich) was also used hard template to create mesoporous structure, which surrounded the preformed ZSM-5 nanocrystals forming hierarchically porous zeolite ZSM-5/SBA-15 composite. This composite catalyst reduced the content of aromatics in gasoline product and presented superior catalytic performance (conversion of more than 80%) during the catalytic cracking of waste cooking oil, which was likely due to the improved molecular transport and reduced density of strong Brønsted acid sties [27]. Moreover, the utilization of polystyrene spheres and sucrose as hard-templating materials provided an effective strategy to introduce intracrystal and interconnected ordered macro-meso-microporosity within the synthesized zeolite Beta single crystals. The novel catalyst introduced in this study offers improved availability of active sites and remarkable thermal stability, particularly in liquid-phase acid-catalytic reactions that involve large or bulky molecules [28]. Inorganic materials, specifically silica spheres and calcium carbonate nanoparticles, are frequently employed as hard templates for the establishment of hierarchically porous materials [29]. One specific example of utilizing inorganic hard templates for the synthesis of hierarchically porous materials is the fabrication of hierarchically macro/microporous ZSM-5 zeolite using silica particles. In this process, the silica spheres played a dual role as silica nutrients and morphology guiding agents. The prepared hierarchically macro/microporous ZSM-5 zeolite demonstrated superior comparative catalytic performance to traditional microporous zeolites in the methanol-to-olefins process. Specifically, it demonstrated a prolonged catalytic durability and increased selectivity for light olefins [30]. Besides, hierarchically porous zeolites with macro-meso-microporous structure were also synthesized by combining many hard templates (polystyrene–silica–carbon composites). The synthesized catalysts were utilized in the cracking reaction of 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene, a compound with bulky molecular structure. Notably, these catalysts exhibited a significant enhancement in both effective diffusion rates and catalytic efficiency in comparison with microporous ZSM-5 and ZSM-5 nanocrystals under optimal reaction conditions. Specifically, the synthesized catalysts demonstrated nine-fold higher optimal diffusion rates and 2.5-fold higher catalytic performance when compared to the aforementioned microporous ZSM-5 catalysts and ZSM-5 nanocrystals [17]. Therefore, the hard templates during the synthesis of hierarchically porous catalysts act as mesoporous directing agent, and sometimes as a feedstock of composite catalysts. In summary, the scheme of hierarchically porous catalysts using the hard-templating method is shown in Fig. 2. Generally, solid hard templating agents are mixed with precursor materials used for the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites, and finally are removed by high-temperature combustion or etching of chemical reagents. These hard templates present direct relationship with the hierarchical structure in catalysts. The diameter and pore volume of mesopore in these hierarchically porous catalysts are determined by the size and amount of hard templating reagents, which need a further quantitative description in the future research. Table 3 2.2 Soft-templating method In contrast to hard template methods, soft-templating methods possess several advantages in terms of their tunable size, adjustable functionality, and increased versatility. During the crystallization process, soft templates play a dual role. They not only act as physical templates for guiding the formation of desired meso- or macroporous structures, but also engage in direct interactions with silica species present in the precursor solution [35,36]. The main soft templating reagents include organosilanes, surfactants, and non-surfactant polymers. In addition to the mentioned methods, the soft template-assisted assembly of zeolite seeds and the utilization of micro-emulsions/reverse micelles have also emerged as effective approaches for synthesizing hierarchically porous zeolites. Organosilanes, such as dimethyloctadecyl[3-(trimethoxysilyl)propyl]ammonium chloride (TPOAC), hexadecyltrimethoxysilane (HDTM), and phenylaminopropyltrimethoxysilane (PHAMPTMS), are always used as mesoporous soft templates during the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites. For example, to overcome the diffusional limitations often associated with conventional microporous zeolite Y, an organosilane template TPOAC was introduced into the precursor solution. The prepared hierarchically porous catalysts, produced as aggregates of 300 nm size containing zeolite nanocrystals (50 nm), displayed a consistent 5.8 nm mesopore and an acidity of 1.73 mmol/g, with a Brønsted/Lewis acid ratio of 0.24. These features suggested their potential for efficient catalytic applications. During the evaluation of catalytic performance for these hierarchically porous catalysts, the optimized catalysts demonstrated a 47.3% of conversion rate of triolein and a 60.3% of selectivity towards hydrocarbons [37]. Besides, hexadecyltrimethoxysilane is indeed an inexpensive surface silanizing reagent that has been utilized for the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites. This compound is commonly used as a structure-directing reagent in the synthesis of mesoporous materials such as zeolites. The initial catalyst synthesis yielded fused crystallites of 10–20 nm diameter interspersed with 13 nm mesopores. Despite deviating from conventional HZSM-5 in structure, the prepared catalysts still maintained high surface property and acid strength. The inclusion of mesopores in the hierarchically porous zeolites greatly improved the production of diesel-range hydrocarbons from the deoxygenation of oleic acid, increasing their yield from around 20–65%. The improved acid center availability in the hierarchical network is accountable for this excellent enhancement [38]. Moreover, an alternative organosilane PHAMPTMS was used to synthesize hierarchically porous ZSM-5 zeolites. Following the precrystallization process at 90℃, PHAMPTMS was added to the gel, along with 5 mol% tetraethylorthosilicate (TEOS). Palladium doping in the prepared hierarchically porous zeolite improved selectivity (90%) and conversions (60–85%) during decarboxylation of fatty acids under mild reaction conditions. Middle distillate hydrocarbons in the catalytic conversion products were the preferred products [39]. Surfactants, such as cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) and 3-aminopropyl triethoxysilane (APTES), are also commonly used as mesoporous templates in the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolite, creating well-defined mesopores within the zeolitic structure. For example, a novel micro-mesoporous silicoaluminophosphate SAPO-34 zeolites have been synthesized directly via introducing CTAB into the conventional gel before the zeolite crystallization process, in which a microporous template (tetraethylammonium hydroxide) was also used. The prepared hierarchically porous catalysts presented an average mesopore size of 9–10 nm and mesopore volume of 0.40–0.68 cm3/g with a higher order and periodicity. The results also indicated that higher CTAB amount in zeolite precursor solution led to increased mesopore volume in the final hierarchically porous zeolites [40]. Besides, APTES-induced mesopores promoted bimolecular reactions (isomerization and aromatization) due to their large pore diameter, facilitating interaction and diffusion of larger reactant molecules. These hierarchically porous catalysts also was modified by chemical silicon vapor deposition method with different external acid strength. Acid sites in different positions (mesopore/outer surface or micropore) played distinct involvement in the reaction of n-heptane catalytic reactions, highlighting the influence of pore location and acid site distribution on selectivity and reaction pathways [41]. Furthermore, a C22–6–6 template, a diquaternary ammonium surfactant [C22H45–N+(CH3)2–C6H12–N+(CH3)2–C6H13]Br2 –, was involved in guiding the synthesis of 2D multi-lamellar zeolite. The quaternary ammonium component of this template played a vital function in guiding the development of micropores within individual layers of the zeolite. Simultaneously, the hydrocarbon tail in this template acted as a filler, occupying the space between the zeolitic layers, thereby contributing to the creation of the distinctive lamellar structure observed in hierarchically porous catalysts (lamellar MFI zeolites) [42]. Besides, a comparison between CTAB and TPOAC as soft mesoporogens had been conducted with different acidity distribution and hierarchical porosity (relative crystallinity of 89.8% and 96.2% and mesopore volume of 0.20 and 0.17 cm3/g), respectively. The results indicated that the HZSM-5/TPOAC catalyst promoted the liquid production and side alkylation reactions, while the HZSM-5/CTAB catalyst promoted the gas products and secondary coking processes [43]. Some combination methods have also been developed including the utilization of soft templates. In our previsions research a in situ growth method with soft template CTAB had been explored, which the mesoporous pores grew on the microporous zeolites with the guiding of CTAB. The composite catalysts Ce-Y/MCM-41 with necessary metal Ce doping (doping amount of about 10%) represented high selectivity (above 70%) on kerosene-range products (C8–C16) [44]. This study provides important reference for catalytic pyrolysis of microalgal lipids via hierarchically porous composite catalysts. In summary, the Fig. 3 illustrates the central process of soft-templating methods employed in the creation of hierarchically porous zeolites, which is applied in catalytic pyrolysis of lipids and bulky molecular compounds. 2.3 Non-templating approach The hierarchically porous catalysts can also be synthesized via non-templating approaches. The main non-templating approaches for synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites include engineering of intergrowth, additive-assisted crystallization, seed-induced synthesis, controlled crystallization, and special structure-directing agents [51,52]. The catalytic activity and selectivity of pyrolysis products for the obtained hierarchically porous catalysts based on non-templating approaches are reviewed as followed. The scheme of non-templating methods for synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolites is shown in the Fig. 4. Mesoporous structures can grow on microporous materials to establish hierarchically porous catalysts, i.e., engineering of intergrowth [42,53]. For example, a core-shell structural zeolite was synthesized with a commercial Y zeolite as core and loosely aggregated Y nanocrystals as shell. This hierarchical cracking catalyst presented rich mesopores with a size of about 40–60 nm and also exhibited excellent catalytic performance, i.e., higher conversion ratio for tri-isopropylbenzene, n-octane, and heavy oil. The evaluation indicated that reactants could be pre-cracked on the accessible external surfaces of the core-shell catalysts and then further deeply cracked in the strong acid centers of micropores [53]. Besides, mesopores (<20 nm) successfully nurtured on microporous Zeolite HY, yielding core-shell structured catalysts MCM-41/HY & MCM-48/HY for Mahua oil-based organic liquid fuel production. The surface area of the synthesized catalysts decreased from 1000 m2/g to about 500–600 m2/g dramatically with an average micro- and mesopore size of 1–2 nm (mesopore size in 35–40 nm). The catalytic cracking experiments for this core-shell composite catalyst indicated higher feedstock conversion (77–97%) and yield of organic liquid fuels (45–70%) in products at an optimized reaction condition of temperature (400 ℃) and WHSV (4.6 h–1) [54]. Additives, such as l-lysine, can be effectively employed to regulate the hydrothermal crystallization process through additive-assisted crystallization. This strategy facilitates the formation of finely developed mesopores within the structure of microporous zeolites. During the synthesis procedure of hierarchically porous zeolites with single-crystalline structure, the amino acid molecule L-lysine effectively chelated with silica and aluminum species. This chelation causes the assembly of non-compactly arranged amorphous aluminosilicate gel particles, creating interstitial pores in the final structure. The as-synthesized hierarchical Beta nanozeolite exhibited a significant surface area of 617 m²/g, indicating substantial interfaces for adsorption and catalytic reactions. Alongside this, it presented a substantial mesopore volume of 0.79 cm³/g, facilitating efficient diffusion and mass transfer of bulky molecules within its porous structure [55]. Hierarchically porous catalysts can also be synthesized by template-free seed-assisted methods, which eliminate the need for secondary templates or organic additives [56]. The effect of different synthesis conditions, specifically hydrothermal treatment parameters including temperature and time, alkali content, and seed crystal dimensions, on the crystalline structure and textural properties of hierarchical zeolite ZSM-5 was investigated in the recent academic study. The synthesized hierarchically porous zeolite ZSM-5 was subjected to evaluation using a model reaction involving the cracking of n-hexane. This examination revealed a noteworthy influence of mesopores on the formation of olefins, particularly when contrasted with the performance of a commercially available microporous catalyst sample [57]. Besides, synthesis of submicron-sized porous ZSM-5 particles was achieved by utilizing a suspension of silicate-1 seeds as a templating reagent, introducing hierarchical porosity on a smaller scale within the ZSM-5 material. The representative specimen, Z5–0.12, was notably characterized by its high crystallinity, substantial BET surface area, and well-established mesopore architecture. These results were contribute to its enhanced catalytic activity in the thermal decomposition of low-density polyethylene, largely associated with the mesoporosity inherent in the hierarchically porous catalysts [56]. Special structure-directing reagents are commonly utilized for fabricating hierarchically porous catalysts [58]. As an illustration, the work of Rajkumar et al. emphasized the synthesis of biphasic ionic liquids and their particular utilization in the field of zeolite synthesis. They prepared several biphasic ionic liquids using pyridinium and imidazolium as base components. The research indicated that among the pyridinium-based reagents the chair conformation was more favorable than the boat conformation in guiding the generation of beta zeolite nanocrystals. Furthermore, it was observed that the generation of inter-particle mesopores in beta zeolite aggregates necessitated a specific angle between two imidazole moieties in the imidazolium-based templating system. Overall, this study provided valuable insights into the influence of various biphasic ionic liquids on the synthesis of zeolites, highlighting the importance of conformational preferences and molecular architectures in determining the resulting zeolite structure and porosity [59]. 3 Post-synthesis pathway and performance of hierarchically porous catalysts Except for template and non-template methods, mesoporous and macroporous structures can also be created by post-synthesis treatment. The main post-synthesis pathways mainly include demetalation via steaming and chemical (acids, alkalis and fluorides) leaching, delamination and recrystallization [63,64]. Chemical leaching (such as acids, alkalis and fluorides) is the typical post-treatment methods to create mesoporous structures in microporous catalysts including desilication and dealumination. The steam or acid leaching is usually used for dealumination, while the alkaline or fluoride leaching is often used for desilication. In summary, the typical scheme or procedure of post-synthesis methods for hierarchically porous zeolites is shown in Fig. 5. 3.1 Desilication The main methods or strategies for desilication are alkaline and fluoride leaching. Microporous zeolite subjected to desilication through the application of an alkaline solution is a widely adopted method for the preparation of hierarchically porous ZSM-5 zeolites [65–67]. It selectively extract silicon from framework atoms in a alkaline medium. For instance, a variety of hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolites have been synthesized through post-treatment using solutions containing NaOH, NaAlO2, Na2CO3, K2CO3, and NaHCO3. Among the alkaline-treated catalysts, the NaHCO3-treated zeolite demonstrated exceptional performance, achieving a conversion rate close to 92% and a remarkable selectivity of around 50% towards light olefins during n-pentane catalytic cracking. This exceptional behavior was observed at an operating temperature of 590 °C for 300 minutes, exceeding the performance of the original zeolites [68]. The catalytic conversion of large molecular feedstocks can be influenced by varying alkaline concentrations. Different alkaline concentrations have been observed to impact the catalytic performance. As an illustration, hierarchical HZSM-5 zeolites were formed through the treatment of HZSM-5 zeolite with NaOH solutions of varying concentrations (0.1 M, 0.3 M, and 0.5 M). The outcomes of the investigation revealed that applying a 0.5 M NaOH solution onto the HZSM-5 zeolite, characterized by a substantial content of acid sites and an expansive cavity volume, yielded a notably elevated aromatic yield of 51.28 wt% [65]. To enhance the efficiency of desilication by base treatment, a postsynthesis modifications had been developed including base (NaOH) treatment and strong acid (HCl) washing for parent Al-rich ZSM-5 zeolite materials. The results during the cracking of triglyceride-rich biomass indicated that the hierarchical ZSM-5 material involved much mesoporosity and presented higher selectivity toward gasoline-range hydrocarbons and light olefins [69]. Furthermore, a tricyclic fuel with energy density of 42.38 MJ/L and a freezing point of lower than −75℃ was produced via a well-defined micro/mesoporous catalyst. This catalyst was synthesized by an simple alkali-treatment (NaOH) method mentioned above, which presented reasonable active acid site distribution and their accessibility [70]. In our previous study, a hierarchically porous zeolite with doping of metal oxides (ZnO, La2O3, and CeO2) had been developed, in which the hierarchical structure was formed via alkali treatment method (Na2CO3). The prepared composite catalysts showed a mesoporous structure (5.28–5.91 nm) and high selectivity on kerosene components (above 40%) and necessary aromatization performance for aromatic hydrocarbon production [71]. Fluoride etching was also conducted to establish hierarchical zeolites during the catalytic cracking of n-hexane. For example, the one-dimensional microporous zeolite EU-1 was etched via NH4F and the etching occurred on the surface of crystals resulting mesoporous pores, which apparently increased the selectivity on propylene from 5.7% to 33.6% [72]. In summary, desilication is not only create mesopores in catalytic materials, but also impacts the aluminum distribution representing various catalytic performance. 3.2 Dealumination Alkaline treatment mostly removed part of the silicon atoms, while aluminum atoms mostly are partly removed by steaming or acid treatment [73,74]. The main methods or strategies for dealumination are steam and acid leaching. For steaming the typical operation is in a water vapor condition with high temperature of more than 500 ℃. For example, a hierarchical ZSM-5 zeolite with a silicon-enriched surface was produced by integrating hydrothermal treatment and tetramethoxysilane (TMOS) modification, with mesoporosity induced via steaming treatment. This technique resulted in a hierarchically porous ZSM-5 zeolite, featuring an enriched silicon-containing surface. The evaluation of cracking performance revealed the concurrent suppression of side reactions and coking, accompanied by a substantial overall yield of propylene and ethylene. Remarkably, the catalyst exhibited robust hydrothermal stability throughout the butylene cracking process, underscoring its excellent performance under these conditions [75]. The main acids, used to dealumination of zeolites, include hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, and various organic acids. For example, the catalytic cracking of 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene via hierarchical Y zeolites had also been conducted and the hierarchically porous structure was created by dealumination by acid washing. The hierarchical porosity in the catalysts promoted deep cracking of feedstock such as five-fold yields of cumene and benzene [76]. The oxalic acid was also used to the establishment of hierarchical Beta zeolite to dealumination, and the prepared catalysts were used to hydroconversion of polyethylene pyrolysis oil, which presented high yield of liquid fuels (about 90%) and negligible olefin content (less than 3.5%) as well as some iso-paraffin (12%) [77]. Although dealumination presents the apparent advantages of simplicity and low cost, it sacrifices framework Al atoms and crystallinity, which causes amorphous structure of particle zeolite framework and partially blocking of the active site. The resulted mesoporous pores are also uncontrollable in terms of pore size and distribution. 3.3 Other post-synthesis pathways Except direct and simple desilication and dealumination processes, combined post-treatment methods were developed [78,79]. For example, the commercial zeolite USY underwent sequential treatments to obtain hierarchical zeolite Y. Initially, dealumination was conducted using oxalic acid. Subsequently, desilication was carried out using ammonium hydroxide in the presence of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide as an assisting agent. Finally, acid washing was carried out using lactic acid. These stepwise procedures successfully yielded hierarchical zeolite Y. The as-prepared catalysts were employed for the catalytic cracking of n-dodecane resulted in conversion ratios ranging from 65% to 95% [80]. Besides, the coupled treatment using NaOH and steaming on HZSM-5 zeolites also synthesized hierarchical catalysts, resulted in excellent performance during glycerol to aromatics procedure, i.e., the highest BTX aromatics yield, the lowest coking rate and the longest catalyst lifetime [81]. A synergistic treatment of zinc chloride and steaming was also developed for zinc-modified ultra-stable Y zeolite, which revealed that selective dealumination and silicon healing promoted the formation of extra-framework silicon and silicon healing of the Al vacancies. The evaluation of catalytic performance presented that higher n-octane and heavy oil catalytic cracking activity and gasoline yield [82]. Besides, the combination of desilication and dealumination can be both conducted to establish hierarchical (or mesoporous) zeolite catalysts. This combination operation can be realized by sequent desilication with NaOH solution (0.25–1.0 mol/L and 95℃) and dealumination with steam (NH4Cl ion exchange and 650℃). The catalytic studies for this hierarchical catalyst indicated that improved gasoline and light cycle oil selectivity for heavy oil cracking as well as improved activity and lifetime in the cracking of 1,3,5-triisopropylbenzene [83]. Table 4 4 Potential of application and future suggestions Generally, the synthesis strategies mentioned in this review can be divided into bottom-up methods and top-down methods, which are responding to the in-situ synthesis and postsynthesis pathways. Application potential for these different synthesis methods have been compared in this section from the point of advantages and disadvantage, synthesis cost and yield, and industrialization potential. The comparison of these different pathways for hierarchically porous catalysts are presented in Table 5. The in-situ synthesis, regardless of hard-templating methods, soft-templating methods or non-templating methods, presents the advantage of various meso- and macroporous structure (pore size and distribution), variable Si/Al ratio and good interconnectivity of pores. However, obvious disadvantages are also shown that the templates need removal via combustion or chemical reagents. Among these in-situ synthesis methods, the hard templates present chemical inertness, availability and versatility. However, the hard templates need removal with high energy consumption and costs finally. The postsynthesis methods, mainly including desilication and dealumination, have the advantages of simple operation, low production costs and easier industrialization, while also present the shortage of poor interconnectivity of pores, modified Si/Al ratio and acidity distribution to their parent zeolites, and mass loss of part Si and Al atoms. In term of synthesis cost or yield for these different synthesis methods, most of templating methods (or bottom-up methods) are not cost-efficiency in industrialization because they all use substantial templates with high costs, while postsynthesis methods are more readily used at an industrial application with the some environmental risk of acids and bases. For example, Rive Technology has developed mesoporous zeolite Y used for FCC process with a commercial scale at the year of 2013 [86]. In summary, the comparison of hierarchically porous catalysts via different routes is rare, especially in terms of large-scale application and their economy evaluation. Large-scale production and commercialization for hierarchically porous catalysts is still be hindered due to economic reasons. Most of the reasons include utilization of organic surfactants or templates, complex or multi-step preparation processes, high energy consumption, and unavoidable waste steams [87]. Hierarchically porous catalysts, especially porous zeolites, have the benefit of enhanced mass diffusion and easily accessible active sites in the multidimensional channels of catalysts. This review presents a thorough survey of the principal synthesis methods utilized for fabricating hierarchically porous catalysts and their application in catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. These methodologies encompass hard/soft templating methods, non-templating methods, and post-synthesis methods. Despite the numerous well-developed synthesis strategies for hierarchically porous catalysts, their practical application in the catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids, particularly microalgal lipids, for the production of liquid hydrocarbon biofuels remains limited. Therefore, some suggestions have been mentioned as followed, which need further research in the future. • Although a large amount of research related to hierarchically porous catalysts have been conducted, synergistic effects or interactions between functions of micropores and mesopores in hierarchically porous catalysts are reported little. The synergistic effects can be further explored in future researches, to establish a comprehensive structure-property-performance relationships for hierarchically porous catalysts. • While there has been extensive research on synthesis of microporous and mesoporous catalysts, there is a scarcity of studies investigating the influence of different micropore/mesopore ratios on the selectivity towards products during catalytic pyrolysis of lipids. What is the optimal balance between the degree of mesoporosity and microporosity in the application of catalytic pyrolysis of lipids? In the future requirement of alternative kerosene (or aviation biofuels) will increase apparently and the affect of micropore/mesopore ratios in hierarchical catalysts can be explored in detail. • There are three typical diffusion named molecular diffusion, Knudsen diffusion and intracrystalline diffusion responding to different pore diameters (0.1–1000 nm). Although there has been extensive research on microporous, mesoporous, and macroporous catalysts in the field of catalytic pyrolysis, there is a lack of comprehensive reports regarding the specific impact of different mesoporous pore size distributions on the catalytic pyrolysis characteristics of lipids. Is there a alternative route via catalytic pyrolysis with hierarchically porous catalysts to produce liquid biofuels? The potential and trend for hierarchically porous zeolites in catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids can be further explored. • Comprehensive techno-economic evaluation should be conducted for various synthesis pathways of hierarchically porous zeolites during catalytic pyrolysis of non-edible lipids. The evaluation is benefit for global development of technical applicable and economical viable processes in the synthesis of hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts. 5 Conclusions Hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts have the properties of fast mass transfer and reduced coking yield due to the formation of mesopores or macropores, which also reserve the advantage of conventional zeolites (high catalytic activity and thermal stability). This review summaries the main synthesis pathways (template methods, non-templating methods and post-synthesis methods) and the characteristics and catalytic performance of the as-synthesized hierarchically porous catalysts. The advantage and shorting of these synthesis pathways have also been compared as well as their application potential in industrial scale. Hard-templating and soft-templating methods present clear theoretical illustration for the synthesis process, while non-templating methods present various synthesis strategies with different theoretical foundation. Besides, post-synthesis methods have apparent advantages in industrial application due to their simplicity and low cost. However, due to their different characteristics and performance for these synthesis pathways in catalytic pyrolysis of lipids to produce liquid biofuels, further research and exploration is still needed to improve their industrial application. The further research suggestion includes synergistic effects between functions of micropores and mesopores, influence of micropore and mesopore ratios on the product selectivity, impact of mesoporous pore size distributions on the catalytic pyrolysis, and comprehensive techno-economic evaluation for various synthesis pathways. coredata.dc:description: Lipids represent a crucial and promising source of alternative liquid hydrocarbons through catalytic pathways. However, catalytic performance of catalysts has been hindered by issues such as coking and low selectivity towards hydrocarbons with desirable carbon distribution. This review critically examines the establishment and application of hierarchically porous structures in catalytic pyrolysis of lipids, exploring their potential as an innovative approach in renewable energy production and resource utilization. The study further investigates the synthesis methods and catalytic performance of hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts, encompassing various techniques such as hard-templating, soft-templating, and non-templating approaches. Various materials, such as carbonaceous substances, polymers, and inorganics, are utilized as sacrificial templates for the hard-templating method. The soft-template methods have the advantages of tunable size, adjustable functionality, and more versatility. Furthermore, the article discusses post-synthesis treatments involving demetalation and chemical leaching. It is noted that hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts demonstrate enhanced catalytic performance due to improved diffusion properties. Future research can emphasize the understanding of synergistic effects between micropores and mesopores and operation cost reduction of catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis and catalytic performance of hierarchically porous catalysts during pyrolysis of lipids to produce liquid hydrocarbons: A review
